training_organizations.name: Illinois DCFS Office of Learning & Development
training_organizations.description: The Illinois Department of Children & Family Services’ training arm, responsible for preparing new child welfare workers and providing ongoing professional development statewide. It runs the foundational training academy where new investigators and caseworkers learn Illinois’ practice model, and offers advanced training (e.g. supervisory skills, forensic interviewing) throughout their careers.

training_organizations.name: Illinois Child Protection Training Academy (Simulation Labs)
training_organizations.description: A partnership with the University of Illinois that uses simulation labs to train new investigators. Trainees at the Child Protection Training Academy participate in realistic mock scenarios (like a simulated home environment) to practice conducting investigations and interviews. This innovative program has become a model for experiential CPS training to improve investigator preparedness.

training_organizations.name: Catholic Charities of Illinois
training_organizations.description: A faith-based nonprofit (with regional agencies in Illinois) that contracts with DCFS to provide foster care case management and related services. Catholic Charities supervises foster homes and works on family reunification and adoption for children in state custody under performance-based contracts:contentReference[oaicite:6]{index=6}.

training_organizations.name: Children’s Home & Aid (Illinois)
training_organizations.description: A statewide nonprofit child welfare agency that holds contracts with Illinois DCFS to manage foster care cases and deliver services. Children’s Home & Aid recruits foster families, places children in homes, and provides caseworkers who oversee the child’s well-being and work towards reunification, operating as part of Illinois’ public-private child welfare system:contentReference[oaicite:7]{index=7}.

training_organizations.name: Lutheran Social Services of Illinois (LSSI)
training_organizations.description: One of Illinois’ largest social service nonprofits, LSSI provides extensive child welfare services under contract with DCFS:contentReference[oaicite:8]{index=8}. It manages foster care placements, licenses foster homes, provides visitation and family reunification services, and offers adoption services – essentially acting as an extension of DCFS in caring for a significant number of children in foster care.

perpetrator_relationships.relationship: Victim Was Child of Boyfriend or Girlfriend

policies.TribalFoster: No, there are no Tribes within the state
policies.TribalReport: No, there are no Tribes within the state
policies.TribalScreen: No, there are no Tribes within the state
policies.DefAge_Specify: Under age 18 and up to 21 if in the care of the agency
policies.ReportAnonymous: General public (not mandated reporters) can remain anonymous
policies.Def_OtherSpecify: Grooming (using a computer online service to seduce, solicit, lure or entice a child or child's guardian to commit a sex offense, distribute sexual photographs, or other unlawful sexual conduct with a child)
policies.FatalitiesReview: Yes, reviews are required for all or some cases
policies.Def_Subtype_Abuse: Abuse includes physical abuse, sexual abuse, excessive corporal punishment, female genital mutilation, illegally providing a controlled substance to a child, and human trafficking
policies.Def_Subtype_Neglect: Neglect includes inadequate clothing, inadequate shelter, malnutrition, abandonment, injurious environment (including domestic violence), and inability to meet parent responsibilities
policies.EquityStaff_Specify: Office of Racial Equity Practice that oversees the Department's efforts to reduce and/or eliminate racial disproportionality, race-based disparities and improve permanency outcomes for children and families of color in the Illinois child welfare system. The Office is staffed by two managerial staff who oversee the direction, planning and support of a system of 30+ Local Action Teams supported by 4 Universities providing data and technical assistance
policies.DefPerp_OtherSpecify: Any person who came to know the child through an official capacity or position of trust
policies.ConsentDecree_Specify: B.H. vs. Smith (also known as B.H. vs. McDonald); Aristotle P. vs. Marc Smith (also known as Aristotle P. vs. McDonald); Burgos vs. Calica (also known as Burgos vs. DCFS); Hill vs. Erickson
policies.Reporter_OtherSpecify: Any funeral home director; Embalmer; Funeral home employee
policies.InvestReq_OtherSpecify: Activities to determine if the investigation is in good faith; Request parent/caregiver mental health information
policies.EquityStaff_OtherSpecify: As a "systems-based" approach to addressing the issue of race and disparities, the Office of Racial Equity Practice impacts and collaborates both internally to Department units and individuals and externally to private agencies, courts, law enforcement, community-based organizations, and university partners
policies.DefHarm_VaryByTypeSpecify: Abuse includes physical injury that may cause death, injury or impairment of physical or emotional condition. Neglect includes harmful environment or conditions.
policies.DefPerp_VaryByTypeSpecify: For neglect, an immediate family member, other person residing in the same home as the child, or the parent's paramour cannot be alleged as the perpetrator unless they were acting as the child's caretaker when the incident occurred
policies.InvestQual_TrainingSpecify: When a Child Protection Specialist is also acting as a Forensic Interviewer for the team, the Child Protection Specialist must first complete 32 hours of approved initial training and maintain a minimum of 8 hours continuing education every two years; To maintain Forensic Interviewer status, the Child Protection Specialist must also participate in the peer review process of their work twice yearly
policies.InvestQual_ExperienceSpecify: 1 year of directly related professional experience with bachelor's degree in social work or master's degree in related human service field; 2 years of directly related professional experience with bachelor's degree in a related human service field; No experience required with master's degree in social work
policies.ReporterPenalty_OtherSpecify: Any funeral home director; Embalmer; Funeral home employee
policies.ReporterTraining_OtherSpecify: Any funeral home director; Embalmer; Funeral home employee
policies.ScreenRiskAssess_OtherSpecify: No tools used; Screeners consider and document risk and safety threats during assessment
policies.CaseManagerQual_ExperienceSpec: 1 year of directly related professional experience with bachelor's degree in social work or master's degree in related human service field; 2 years of directly related professional experience with bachelor's degree in a related human service field; No experience required with master's degree in social work
policies.InvestReq_MedEvalCases_Specify: Head injuries; Internal injuries; Burns; Poison/noxious substances; Wounds; Bone fractures; Cuts, bruises, welts, abrasions, and oral injuries; Human bites; Sprains/dislocations; Substance misuse; Torture; Sexually transmitted diseases; Sexual penetrations; Medical neglect; Failure to thrive (non-organic); Malnutrition (non-organic); Medical neglect of disabled infants
policies.ScreenerQual_ExperienceSpecify: 2 years for individuals with a bachelor's degree in a human service field; 1 year for individuals with a master's degree in a human service field; 1 year for individuals with a bachelor's degree in social work
policies.ExtFosterCare_Reentry_OtherSpec: Any time prior to a minor's 21st birthday, the court may reinstate wardship and open a previously closed case when: (a) wardship and guardianship of the Juvenile Court was vacated: (i) in the case of a minor over the age of 18; (ii) closure of a case in the case of a minor under the age of 18 who has been partially or completely emancipated ; or (iii) based on the minor's attaining the age of 19 years; (b) the minor is not presently a ward of the court nor is there a petition for adjudication of wardship pending on behalf of the minor
policies.ExtFosterCare_Request_OtherSpec: Any time prior to a minor's 21st birthday, pursuant to a supplemental petition filed, the court may reinstate wardship
